docs.lead_paragraph: Motherhood without marriage among younger women across the country is both a symbol of the transforming family and a hint of coming generational change.

headline.main: For Women Under 30, Most Births Occur Outside Marriage
headline.print_headline: Unwed Mothers Now a Majority Before Age of 30

docs.abstract: More than half of births to women under age 30 in the United States occur outside of marriage; after a steady rise for five decades, number has now crossed threshold of a majority; once largely limited to poor and minority women, the fastest growth in unwed mothers in the last two decades was among whites in their 20s; surge of births outside marriage is both a symbol of the transforming family and a hint of a coming generational shift.
docs.snippet: Motherhood without marriage among younger women across the country is both a symbol of the transforming family and a hint of coming generational change.

byline.original: By JASON DePARLE and SABRINA TAVERNISE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said it was worried about possible heart problems and birth defects with Qnexa, a weight-loss drug.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Still Wary of Diet Pill’s Side Effects
headline.main: Side Effects of Diet Pill Still Concern Regulators
headline.print_headline: Side Effects Of Diet Pill Still Concern Regulators

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration says it is worried about possible heart problems and birth defects with Qnexa, a weight-loss drug; committee of advisers to the FDA will consider again whether the drug, developed by Vivus, should be approved.
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said it was worried about possible heart problems and birth defects with Qnexa, a weight-loss drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of the rule mandating insurance coverage for birth control contend that some contraception methods amount to abortion, but experts say the drugs work prior to fertilization.

headline.seo: Religious Groups Equate Abortion With Some Contraceptives
headline.main: Religious Groups Equate Some Contraceptives With Abortion
headline.print_headline: Groups Equate Abortion With Some Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic bishops and some evangelical groups assert that plan to require that employees of religiously affiliated institutions must receive insurance coverage for birth control also effectively requires coverage of some forms of abortion because some contraceptives could potentially prevent the implantation of a fertilized egg.
docs.snippet: Opponents of the rule mandating insurance coverage for birth control contend that some contraception methods amount to abortion, but experts say the drugs work prior to fertilization.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and ERIK ECKHOLM

headline.main: Parental Quandary Considered: A Daughter's Pregnant Teenage Friend

docs.abstract: Advice to a mother whose daughter's teenage friend is pregnant? Be supportive, and let your daughters in on every difficult moment.
docs.snippet: Advice to a mother whose daughter's teenage friend is pregnant? Be supportive, and let your daughters in on every difficult moment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Supporters and opponents of President Obama’s health coverage requirement for all employers see it as a potent weapon for the November elections.

headline.seo: Both Sides Eager to Take Contraception Mandate Debate to Voters
headline.main: Both Sides Eager to Take Birth Control Coverage Issue to Voters
headline.print_headline: Both Sides Eager to Take Birth Control Coverage Issue to Voters

docs.abstract: Furor over Pres Obama’s birth control mandate has become entrenched, with supporters and opponents alike calling the subject a potent weapon for the 2012 elections; religious conservatives and Republicans have dismissed Pres Obama's effort to soften the rule, refusing to relinquish an issue that allows them to portray Obama as a threat to religious liberty and traditional values; some liberal groups feel the issue will play in favor of Democrats, mobilizing the powerful womens' vote.
docs.snippet: Supporters and opponents of President Obama’s health coverage requirement for all employers see it as a potent weapon for the November elections.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The 4-year-old Malachy beat out a Dalmatian, German shepherd, Doberman pinscher, Irish setter, a Kerry blue terrier and wire-haired dachshund for Westminster’s 115th overall best in show title.

headline.seo: Malachy, a Pekingese, Wins Westminster’s Best in Show
headline.main: Pekingese Steals Show Along With Westminster’s Top Honor
headline.print_headline: Pekingese Steals Show Along With Westminster’s Top Honor

docs.abstract: Pekingese Malachy wins Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show; it is the fourth win for the breed in the show's history, and the 10th for the toy group; Malachy took second place at the 2011 show.
docs.snippet: The 4-year-old Malachy beat out a Dalmatian, German shepherd, Doberman pinscher, Irish setter, a Kerry blue terrier and wire-haired dachshund for Westminster’s 115th overall best in show title.

docs.lead_paragraph: Francis Spufford’s “Red Plenty” follows a cast of characters around the Soviet Union of the 1950s and ’60s as Communist theory lost its promise.

headline.main: The Soviet Goose That Laid Golden Eggs
headline.print_headline: The Soviet Goose That Laid Golden Eggs

docs.abstract: Dwight Garner reviews book Red Plenty by Francis Spufford.
docs.snippet: Francis Spufford’s “Red Plenty” follows a cast of characters around the Soviet Union of the 1950s and ’60s as Communist theory lost its promise.
